private_information: I can move exactly one disk at a time.
I can place a smaller disk on top of a larger disk but never place a larger disk on top of a smaller one.
I initially perceive all disks stacked on the left peg from smallest on top to largest on bottom.
disk_mover.goal: Move the entire stack of disks from the left peg to the right peg following the rules.

private_information: I validate the legality of moves according to the Tower of Hanoi rules.
I can enumerate and check successor states produced by single-disk moves.
constraint_checker.goal: Ensure every planned move respects the constraint that no larger disk is placed on a smaller disk.

orchestrator.goal: Produce a single PDDL domain and problem pair that solves the Tower of Hanoi instance with 8 disks and three pegs, ready for the FastDownwards solver.

public_information: There are three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are eight disks labeled A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H from smallest (A) to largest (H).
Initially, left peg has (top→bottom) A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H. Middle and right pegs are empty.
The goal is to have left peg empty, middle peg empty, and right peg with (top→bottom) A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H.
Rules: move exactly one disk at a time and never place a larger disk on top of a smaller disk.

describe.system_prompt: You are the disk_mover agent. Provide a concise, actionable description of the moves you can perform, the observations you have about the initial configuration, and any assumptions you need to make to plan single-disk moves. Do not emit PDDL. Focus on capabilities, preconditions, and effects in plain descriptive language.
describe.prompt: Your name is disk_mover. You are in an environment with the following public information: {environment->public_information} You have the following private knowledge: {agents->disk_mover->private_information} This is your goal: {agents->disk_mover->goal} Provide a clear description of available actions, their preconditions, and their effects in natural language, and list any assumptions. Do not produce PDDL.

describe.system_prompt: You are the constraint_checker agent. Provide a concise description of the constraints you enforce, how you verify move legality, and any checks you perform on successor states. Do not emit PDDL. Provide checks and invariants in plain descriptive language.
describe.prompt: Your name is constraint_checker. You are in an environment with the following public information: {environment->public_information} You have the following private knowledge: {agents->constraint_checker->private_information} This is your goal: {agents->constraint_checker->goal} Provide a clear list of constraints and verification steps you would apply to candidate moves or plans. Do not produce PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent PDDL modeling and planning. Integrate knowledge from other agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem pair suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep agent actions distinct if multiple agent perspectives are represented. The produced PDDL must model three pegs (left, middle, right), eight disks A through H ordered by size, the initial stack on left, and the goal stack on right. Target the FastDownwards solver by using constructs compatible with it.
pddl.prompt: There are multiple agents providing descriptive knowledge about actions and constraints. You will receive their descriptions and must integrate them into a single, consistent PDDL domain and problem that solves the following global goal: {agents->orchestrator->goal} Here is the knowledge from the disk_mover agent: {disk_mover_knowledge} Here is the knowledge from the constraint_checker agent: {constraint_checker_knowledge} Think step by step, resolve naming or assumption inconsistencies if necessary, keep action schemas explicit and separate, and output a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem ready for FastDownwards. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
